subject: Do we ♥  Unicode?
header: lots of great articles this week. Way too many! And many of them have all kinds of funny Unicode characters in their title or description. Let's see if the Perl Weekly can already handle those? If you see any breakage, please let me know!
(Actually I got an exception from Encode during the conversion and Carp::Always helped me locate the source of the problem. See article below.

entries.title: How I manage my Perl distributions
entries.text: There are some large Perl-based applications out there that use their own way of packaging and distributing the code, but Steven Haryanto belives it is better to use the same toolchain as is used for CPAN distributions. Even if the application does not end up on CPAN. Even if it is an in-house or other proprietary application. (I tend to agree.) In this article he describes how he handles the process.

entries.title: How to use the debugger with Moose
entries.text: I have been a long-time fan of the command line debugger that comes with Perl, but in certain cases, especially when using Moose, it has issues. Now Ovid shows a solution using DB::Skip written by  Christian Walde.

entries.title: Dist::Zilla ♥ encoding
entries.text: Last weekend there was a mini hackathon at Ricardo Signes' house. David Golden tells us about the imprvements they made to Dist::Zilla and which plugins might need further work in order to make sure everything works fine with UTF-8.

entries.title: Parallel DNS lookups using AnyEvent
entries.text: An explanation and a full example script by Sebastian Willing.

entries.title: Acme-oop-ism Part Two: Type::Tiny
entries.text: As Toby Inkster explains: 'Acme-oop-ism is about writing code that works in Moose, Mouse and Moo.' His work allows the deprecation of several modules in favour of one that can handle all 3 OOP systems.

entries.title: Enable Backtraces with Carp::Always (Modern Perl Tips)
entries.text: This module will attach a stack-trace to every warning and exception, without modifying the code!

entries.title: CPAN modules for converting markdown to HTML
entries.text: Just as I am going to need one, Neil Bowers went over 9 CPAN modules converting Markdown to HTML. I love these comparisions, but it also somehow disturbs me. Frankly in many cases I'd just would like to be told 'use this' and not need to think about it much.

entries.title: POD Web View
entries.text: A fun web application written by Michał Wojciechowski using Perl Dancer. You type in some POD (or upload a file or give it a URL) and it will convert it to HTML and show it in search.cpan.org style, or MetaCPAN style, or GitHub style.

entries.title: Plotly - Scientific Graphing Libraries
entries.text: It says on the web page: 'Modern, drop-in alternatives for matplotlib, ggplot2, and MATLAB plotting routines with the added bonus of interactive, web-ready output.' Go try it!

entries.title: Perl DBD::ODBC 1.44_4 released to the CPAN
entries.text: This is a development releases, but as Martin Evans writes this is going to be 1.45. So if you depend on DBD::ODBC, you'd better test it. See changes in the latest development versions.

entries.title: Parsing JSON with a single Regex
entries.text: brian d foy explains the crazy regex written by Randal Schwartz to the Houston Perl Mongers and to all of us.

entries.title: Perl Catalyst 'Hamburg' Development Release 4 on CPAN
entries.text: Thank to John Napiorkowski we have regular reporting in the development of the Catalyst web framework. Several improvements especially in the area of better PSGI support to enable mounting other PSGI based applications inside a Catalyst app.

entries.title: Writing Non-Blocking Applications with Mojolicious: Part 1
entries.text: Joel Berger starts the series of articles by asking the question: 'Why should I chose Mojolicious versus one of the other major Perl web frameworks?'. His point is that just as Node.js, Mojolicious was also designed non-blocking in mind. He then goes ahead and shows two versions of a pastebin application.
